channel.title: MorningBrew as a feed
channel.description: This is a feed of recent MorningBrew articles published by Huginn

item.title: Meatpacking companies exaggerated shortages to stay open, new report says
item.description: . Become smarter in just 5 minutesGet the daily email that makes reading the news actually enjoyable. The North American Meat Institute said the report “cherry picks data to support a narrative that is completely unrepresentative of the early days of an unprecedented national emergency.” Well, a new House subcommittee report concluded that meatpacking companies  exaggerated product shortages during the height of the pandemic to keep plants open and skirt Covid health guidelines. According to the report, Tyson even drafted the executive order issued by former President Trump in April 2020 to keep plants open.
item.author: Matty Merritt

item.title: This is the first-ever image of the supermassive black hole at the center of our galaxy
item.description: . Become smarter in just 5 minutesGet the daily email that makes reading the news actually enjoyable. css-y2oq5g[data-hover][data-disabled]{background:var(--colors-primary);opacity:0.5;}SubscribeFor all the visual thinkers who can’t picture what a black hole 4 million times more massive than the sun and 26,000 light-years away from Earth would look like without a photo: This should help!
item.author: Max Knoblauch

item.title: Billionaires' wealth evaporates amid stock market plunge
item.description: . Become smarter in just 5 minutesGet the daily email that makes reading the news actually enjoyable. Well, one spillover effect is that Elon Musk is still searching for partners to help him alleviate some of the financial risk from buying Twitter for $44 billion. The richest 10 people got $1.3 billion wealthier each day. css-y2oq5g{display:-webkit-inline-box;display:-webkit-inline-flex;display:-ms-inline-flexbox;display:inline-flex;-webkit-appearance:none;-moz-appearance:none;-ms-appearance:none;appearance:none;-webkit-align-items:center;-webkit-box-align:center;-ms-flex-align:center;align-items:center;-webkit-box-pack:center;-ms-flex-pack:center;-webkit-justify-content:center;justify-content:center;-webkit-user-select:none;-moz-user-select:none;-ms-user-select:none;user-select:none;position:relative;white-space:nowrap;vertical-align:middle;outline:2px solid transparent;outline-offset:2px;width:auto;line-height:1.2;border-radius:var(--chakra-radii-md);font-weight:var(--chakra-fontWeights-semibold);transition-property:var(--chakra-transition-property-common);transition-duration:var(--chakra-transition-duration-normal);height:var(--chakra-sizes-10);min-width:var(--chakra-sizes-10);font-size:var(--chakra-fontSizes-md);-webkit-padding-start:var(--chakra-space-4);padding-inline-start:var(--chakra-space-4);-webkit-padding-end:var(--chakra-space-4);padding-inline-end:var(--chakra-space-4);color:var(--chakra-colors-white);background:var(--colors-primary);radius:var(--border-radius);}.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Crypto-backed mortgages let HODLers become homeowners
item.description: . )Become smarter in just 5 minutesGet the daily email that makes reading the news actually enjoyable. “These companies are unproven to be able to manage that catastrophic risk from their side,” Carvell said. In order for crypto mortgages to be widely adopted, he said, “a lot of users need to have digital assets that have significantly appreciated in value.” css-y2oq5g[data-hover][data-disabled]{background:var(--colors-primary);opacity:0.5;}SubscribeRupena declined to share the exact number of crypto mortgages that Milo has executed, but he said the company has already issued over $10 million worth of loans in crypto mortgages. Though the industry is growing, it’s not for the average crypto HODLer.Ledn, Figure, and Milo all allow customers to take out mortgages by putting up cryptocurrency as collateral without cashing it out, unlike a standard mortgage where a new homeowner has the pleasure of handing over their down payment in cash on closing. Crypto mortgage companies let customers hold onto their digital currencies for a couple of reasons: First, crypto believers don’t want to liquidate their portfolio and transfer it back to dollars, just in case the price of crypto continues to rise and they miss post-liquidation gains. Rupena said that’s “incredibly encouraging,” since he’s looking for customers who want to use crypto to buy their home without selling their digital assets (and paying the subsequent taxes). Though this threat of margin calls and freefalling crypto values may be anxiety-inducing, Milo CEO Josip Rupena argues that “overall, it’s a safer mortgage transaction” than some traditional mortgages, since homeowners can liquidate their crypto before going into foreclosure.
item.author: Ashwin Rodrigues

item.title: Atlanta rapper Young Thug’s own lyrics could be used against him in RICO charge
item.description: . Become smarter in just 5 minutesGet the daily email that makes reading the news actually enjoyable. Georgia prosecutors allege that Williams is one of the organizers of the Atlanta gang Young Slime Life (YSL), which has been accused of a number of violent crimes, including a 2015 murder. Williams’s lawyer told the LA Times the claims were “frivolous” and that they will “fight it and litigate it ethically, and lawfully and zealously.” —MM The law allows the state to find multiple parties guilty if it can prove that everyone in the organization committed two or more serious crimes that were part of a larger racketeering plan. In the indictment, prosecutors named nine songs that they claim are evidence of Williams’s criminal activity. Behind the charges is a 1970s statute created to take down mobsters, known as the Racketeer Influenced and Corrupt Organizations (RICO) Act. Prosecutors are using the state’s RICO law to charge Williams and his associates—including rappers Yak Gotti, Gunna, and Williams’s brother Unfoonk—with crimes they may not have committed, but were involved in vis-a-vis YSL.
item.author: Matty Merritt

item.title: Coinbase trading volumes, revenue are down
item.description: . Become smarter in just 5 minutesGet the daily email that makes reading the news actually enjoyable. —JW css-1dlcpt7[data-readonly]{box-shadow:none!
item.author: Jamie Wilde

item.title: Inflation dipped but stayed red-hot in April
item.description: . Big picture: Last month, a record share of Americans said that inflation was their No. 1 financial problem, and the people in charge are playing the blame game. Become smarter in just 5 minutesGet the daily email that makes reading the news actually enjoyable. In one dramatic example, airfares jumped 18.6% annually last month for their biggest gain on record. That’s especially worrisome because, unlike inflation in goods, services inflation can’t be solved by working out supply chain kinks. Used vehicle prices continued their descent, and apparel prices also dropped.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Young people are split on whether companies should have a public stance on abortion access
item.description: . Become smarter in just 5 minutesGet the daily email that makes reading the news actually enjoyable. Grant ThomasReimbursement split: When asked if private companies should cover the cost of travel for employees who need to go out of state to receive abortions, 52% said yes and 48% said no. Grant ThomasMoving factor: Immediately following a final SCOTUS decision, 23 states could restrict abortion access, including 13 states ready with “trigger laws” to outlaw abortion completely. stance: 41% of respondents think companies should make public statements regarding abortion rights in light of the recent SCOTUS news. css-1dlcpt7[data-readonly]{box-shadow:none! When asked how important abortion access is in deciding where they’ll live in the future, 30% of respondents said “not important at all,” 16% said “a little important” and the remaining 54% were split between “very important” and “somewhat important.” In a Generation Lab–Morning Brew poll, we asked 813 young people around the country how abortion access would influence their future career choices and whether they think companies should make public statements on the matter. 32% said companies shouldn’t and 26% said they weren’t sure. A few hours before Politico published the draft opinion, Amazon did announce it would reimburse employees for some abortion-related travel if they are on Amazon’s health insurance.
item.author: Matty Merritt

item.title: Algorithmic stablecoin terra’s value plummets
item.description: . Become smarter in just 5 minutesGet the daily email that makes reading the news actually enjoyable. Even as terra clawed back some of its value on Tuesday, its plunge sent shockwaves through the crypto industry, raising existential questions around the stability—and viability—of stablecoins. A stablecoin is a crypto that is tied to the value of government-backed currency, and the most popular ones right now are all pegged to $1. css-y2oq5g[data-hover][data-disabled]{background:var(--colors-primary);opacity:0.5;}SubscribeTerraUSD is a type of cryptocurrency known as an algorithmic stablecoin, and its whole schtick is that it’s always supposed to be worth $1. To keep the coin from crashing completely, the organization behind terra is dipping into its stockpile of $3.5 billion worth of bitcoin to lend to trading platforms. That incentivizes terra owners to trade back and forth between the two currencies to make a profit, aka arbitrage. —JW css-1dlcpt7[data-readonly]{box-shadow:none! When terra’s price fluctuates, a financial algorithm kicks in to adjust luna’s price so that terra is always equivalent to $1 worth of luna. Here’s how terra works:A cryptocurrency called luna works in conjunction with terra. The crypto community losing faith in terra's $1 value has triggered what some have compared to a bank run. Algorithmic stablecoins, on the other hand, don’t have any collateral behind them.
item.author: Jamie Wilde

item.title: Apple is officially retiring the iPod
item.description: . Become smarter in just 5 minutesGet the daily email that makes reading the news actually enjoyable. In 2006, it released the iPod Nano that came in colors we were begging to infiltrate the tech world (lime green and hot pink). The tech giant said yesterday that it will discontinue its iconic iPod Touch, the final remaining product of its music-player-only lineup, marking the official end of the era that revolutionized digital music. —MM css-1dlcpt7[data-readonly]{box-shadow:none! And in 2007, the very first iPod that you could smudge up with your greasy fingers arrived.
item.author: Matty Merritt

item.title: Secretary Yellen: Abortion restrictions could damage economy
item.description: . Become smarter in just 5 minutesGet the daily email that makes reading the news actually enjoyable. Two-thirds of the group that was unable to get abortions were living in poverty within six months, compared to 45% of the group that was able to receive the procedure. “One aspect of a satisfying life is being able to feel that you have the financial resources to raise a child,” Yellen responded. “I believe that eliminating the rights of women to make decisions about when and whether to have children would have very damaging effects on the economy and would set women back decades,” Secretary Yellen told lawmakers yesterday. Officials supporting that law have argued that Roe v. Scholars argue that abortion access was an important factor in raising that rate to 57.4% by 2019. css-y2oq5g[data-hover][data-disabled]{background:var(--colors-primary);opacity:0.5;}SubscribeFallout from a leaked draft of a Supreme Court ruling that would overturn Roe v. A 2020 paper published by the National Bureau of Economic Research found that being denied abortion access causes bankruptcies and evictions experienced by women to rise by 81%, and increases the amount of debt women hold that is 30+ days past due by 78%. —MK css-1dlcpt7[data-readonly]{box-shadow:none!
item.author: Max Knoblauch

item.title: Algorithmic stablecoin terra’s value plummets
item.description: . Become smarter in just 5 minutesGet the daily email that makes reading the news actually enjoyable. Even as terra clawed back most of its value on Tuesday, algorithmic stablecoins became the pineapple-on-pizza debate of the crypto community. css-y2oq5g[data-hover][data-disabled]{background:var(--colors-primary);opacity:0.5;}SubscribeTerraUSD is a type of cryptocurrency known as an algorithmic stablecoin, and its whole schtick is that it’s always supposed to be worth $1. When terra’s price fluctuates, a financial algorithm kicks in to adjust luna’s price so that terra is always equivalent to $1 worth of luna. —JW css-1dlcpt7[data-readonly]{box-shadow:none! That incentivizes terra owners to trade back and forth between the two currencies to make a profit, aka arbitrage. Here’s how terra works:A cryptocurrency called luna works in conjunction with terra. A stablecoin is worth a set amount of a fiat currency, and the most popular ones right now are all pegged to $1. The crypto community losing faith in terra's $1 value has triggered what Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen called a run. To keep the currency from crashing completely, the organization behind terra is dipping into its stockpile of $3.5 billion worth of bitcoin to lend to trading platforms.
item.author: Jamie Wilde

item.title: Apple is officially retiring the iPod
item.description: . Become smarter in just 5 minutesGet the daily email that makes reading the news actually enjoyable. In 2006, it released the iPod Nano that came in colors we were begging to infiltrate the tech world (lime green and hot pink). The tech giant said yesterday that it will discontinue its iconic iPod Touch, the final remaining product of its music-player-only lineup, marking the official end of the era that revolutionized digital music. —MM css-1dlcpt7[data-readonly]{box-shadow:none! item.title: College students are split on whether companies should have a public stance on abortion access
item.description: . Become smarter in just 5 minutesGet the daily email that makes reading the news actually enjoyable. Moving factor: Immediately following a final SCOTUS decision, 23 states could restrict abortion access, including 13 states ready with “trigger laws” to outlaw abortion completely. Reimbursement split: When asked if private companies should cover the cost of travel for employees who need to go out of state to receive abortions, 52% said yes and 48% said no. In a Generation Lab–Morning Brew poll, we asked 813 college students around the country how abortion access would influence their future career choices and whether they think companies should make public statements on the matter. When students were asked how important abortion access is in deciding where they’ll live in the future, 30% said “not important at all,” 16% said “a little important” and the remaining 54% were split between “very important” and “somewhat important.” css-1dlcpt7[data-readonly]{box-shadow:none! stance: 41% of college students think companies should make public statements regarding abortion rights in light of the recent SCOTUS news. 32% said companies shouldn’t and 26% said they weren’t sure. A few hours before Politico published the draft opinion, Amazon did announce it would reimburse employees for some abortion-related travel if they are on Amazon’s health insurance.
item.author: Matty Merritt

item.title: Secretary Yellen: Abortion restrictions could damage economy
item.description: . Become smarter in just 5 minutesGet the daily email that makes reading the news actually enjoyable. Two-thirds of the group that was unable to get abortions were living in poverty within six months, compared to 45% of the group that was able to receive the procedure. “One aspect of a satisfying life is being able to feel that you have the financial resources to raise a child,” Yellen responded. “I believe that eliminating the rights of women to make decisions about when and whether to have children would have very damaging effects on the economy and would set women back decades,” Secretary Yellen told lawmakers yesterday. Officials supporting that law have argued that Roe v. Scholars argue that abortion access was an important factor in raising that rate to 57.4% by 2019. css-y2oq5g[data-hover][data-disabled]{background:var(--colors-primary);opacity:0.5;}SubscribeFallout from a leaked draft of a Supreme Court ruling that would overturn Roe v. —MK css-1dlcpt7[data-readonly]{box-shadow:none! Progressives like Senator Bernie Sanders have pushed Democrats to eliminate the filibuster and codify Roe v. A 2020 paper published by the National Bureau of Economic Research found that women being denied abortion access causes bankruptcies and evictions to rise by 81%, and increases the amount of debt women hold that is 30+ days past due by 78%. Republican Senator Tim Scott of South Carolina pushed back on Secretary Yellen’s comments, calling her framing of the issue in economic terms callous and harsh. Wade into law with 50 votes rather than the necessary 60.
item.author: Max Knoblauch

item.title: Passing the vibe check
item.description: How to hang with Gen ZFrom transparency to safety, it’s clear that Gen Z’s priorities aren’t mysterious or superficial. From ethics to social issues, here are five areas that motivate Gen Z, plus a few Gen Z vocab words to add to your dictionary. This means high APRs and “buy now, pay later” offers are kinda sus4—and banks that don’t charge overdraft fees and do ditch their punitive debt cycles are likely to score the biggest W with Gen Z. )And for all our numbers people: 7 in 10 Gen Zers want safety and security in their lives. Brands have the reach, money, and scale to create change—change that Gen Z is adamant about seeing in the world. For retailers, this means Gen Zers want to walk into safe stores and use products made with safe materials. No. 5: Social issuesThe easiest way to earn Gen Z’s trust? Gen Z shoppers stan1 ethical brands—and they’ll go out of their way to shop at retailers that go the extra mile to treat their workforces with dignity. Gen Z is made up of many individuals and smaller demographic groups, and their collective ideals are built on style and substance. No. 1: EthicsGen Z supports brands that take care of their employees. But first: Why should Gen Z matter to me? Naturally, brands that use their influence to take a stance on important issues will be brands that Gen Z not only high-key5 loves but also trusts.
item.author: Morning Brew

item.title: The week ahead: May 9
item.description: . Become smarter in just 5 minutesGet the daily email that makes reading the news actually enjoyable. While much of the pageantry will be the same as ever (a huge military parade through Moscow’s Red Square, for example), there’s also a great deal of apprehension this year over whether President Vladimir Putin will announce an escalation of what Russia has called a “special military operation” in Ukraine into a full-scale war. Everything else:The Senate will vote on legislation that would codify abortion rights into law on Wednesday. css-y2oq5g[data-hover][data-disabled]{background:var(--colors-primary);opacity:0.5;}SubscribeVictory Day in Russia: Today Russia will celebrate its most important holiday, Victory Day, which commemorates the Soviet Union’s defeat of Nazi Germany in 1945. css-1dlcpt7[data-readonly]{box-shadow:none! Wednesday is Eat What You Want Day (this has the raw cookie dough lobby written all over it). Inflation data: Wednesday’s Consumer Price Index report is expected to show a drop in inflation from last month’s blistering 8.5% pace, but not by much. css-1dlcpt7[data-focus]{z-index:1;border-color:var(--colors-primary);box-shadow:var(--chakra-shadows-none);}.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Tech startups feel the pinch from rising interest rates
item.description: . Become smarter in just 5 minutesGet the daily email that makes reading the news actually enjoyable. Tiger Global, the hedge fund with the most investments in private billion-dollar startups, is going through one of the worst stretches of any hedge fund in history, falling 44% so far this year and 15% in April alone.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: US solar industry in state of chaos during tariff probe
item.description: . Become smarter in just 5 minutesGet the daily email that makes reading the news actually enjoyable. It’s all because of one companyIn March, a small solar panel manufacturer in San Jose, Auxin Solar, asked the Commerce Dept. According to the Solar Energy Industries Association, 318 solar projects around the country, including one in Texas that would have powered more than 10,000 homes, have been canceled or delayed in recent weeks. to launch an investigation into whether Chinese solar products were being illegally funneled through other Asian countries on their way to the US. css-y2oq5g[data-hover][data-disabled]{background:var(--colors-primary);opacity:0.5;}SubscribeThe US solar industry is a hot mess right now. Big picture: The Biden administration is having a tough time squaring the industry-wide freeze with its goal of halving the cost of solar electricity by 2030. Solar advocates are livid with Auxin and the fedsRenewables leaders are flabbergasted that solar development has been put on ice at a time when the US needs to be ramping up clean-energy production to meet its climate targets. And receiving no imports from those countries is a big problem, because 82% of the most popular solar modules in the US come from there.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Museums reckon with their ‘finders keepers’ problem
item.description: . Become smarter in just 5 minutesGet the daily email that makes reading the news actually enjoyable. But now, individual museums under the Smithsonian’s umbrella (including the National Portrait Gallery and the National Museum of American History) can individually decide to return artifacts, even when their hand isn’t forced by the law. css-y2oq5g{display:-webkit-inline-box;display:-webkit-inline-flex;display:-ms-inline-flexbox;display:inline-flex;-webkit-appearance:none;-moz-appearance:none;-ms-appearance:none;appearance:none;-webkit-align-items:center;-webkit-box-align:center;-ms-flex-align:center;align-items:center;-webkit-box-pack:center;-ms-flex-pack:center;-webkit-justify-content:center;justify-content:center;-webkit-user-select:none;-moz-user-select:none;-ms-user-select:none;user-select:none;position:relative;white-space:nowrap;vertical-align:middle;outline:2px solid transparent;outline-offset:2px;width:auto;line-height:1.2;border-radius:var(--chakra-radii-md);font-weight:var(--chakra-fontWeights-semibold);transition-property:var(--chakra-transition-property-common);transition-duration:var(--chakra-transition-duration-normal);height:var(--chakra-sizes-10);min-width:var(--chakra-sizes-10);font-size:var(--chakra-fontSizes-md);-webkit-padding-start:var(--chakra-space-4);padding-inline-start:var(--chakra-space-4);-webkit-padding-end:var(--chakra-space-4);padding-inline-end:var(--chakra-space-4);color:var(--chakra-colors-white);background:var(--colors-primary);radius:var(--border-radius);}. And in the US, there have been ongoing efforts to return Native American artifacts: The Museum of Natural History has given back over 1,850 since 1998 to American Indigenous communities. Italy loaned back a fragment of the Parthenon Marbles (a goddess’s foot) this year. —JW
item.author: Jamie Wilde

item.description: . Become smarter in just 5 minutesGet the daily email that makes reading the news actually enjoyable. For YouTube, I’m building a Bubble Wrap music box. So you know a small music box with a barrel? item.title: Gucci to start accepting crypto in stores
item.description: . Become smarter in just 5 minutesGet the daily email that makes reading the news actually enjoyable. Gucci will start accepting $SHIB—as well as more than 10 other cryptocurrencies—at select stores later this month and nationwide this summer as part of the luxury sector’s wider push into crypto. But it’s playing catch-up to other luxury brands that have rushed to accept crypto for goods:Off-White announced in March that its flagship stores started taking crypto as payment. —JW css-1dlcpt7[data-readonly]{box-shadow:none! Bottom line: A collab between luxury brands and crypto may be the best match since jazz and rain, because both rely on hype and clout. How it’ll work: In-store shoppers who want to reinvest their bitcoin into a crossbody will be emailed a QR code that allows them to complete the transaction using their crypto wallets. Philipp Plein is one-upping its peers by building a London store where customers can pay in crypto, browse an NFT gallery, and upgrade certain purchases with a corresponding NFT they can wear in the virtual world of Decentraland.
item.author: Jamie Wilde

item.title: Starbucks wants its own meeting with the president after it met with union organizers
item.description: . Become smarter in just 5 minutesGet the daily email that makes reading the news actually enjoyable. After Starbucks union organizers met with President Biden and other Washington A-listers on Thursday, the company sent an angry letter to the White House requesting its own meeting, saying, “We are deeply concerned that Workers United…was invited to the meeting while not inviting official Starbucks representatives.”
item.author: Matty Merritt
